questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with intensely itchy, flat-topped, violaceous papules on the flexor surfaces of her wrists. On examination, the lesions are polygonal in shape and show fine white lines. She also reports mild discomfort when brushing her teeth. All of the following are included in the 5 Ps except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pedunculated lesions are not part of the classic 5 Ps that describe the hallmark morphology of this papular dermatosis.

  • The 5 Ps describe the characteristic clinical appearance:
    • Pruritic(Option D) – intensely itchy
    • Purple – violaceous hue
    • Polygonal – angular borders
    • Planar(Option B) – flat-topped
    • Papules(Option A) – small, raised lesions
  • Lesions may exhibit Wickham’s striae—fine, white reticulations best seen on mucosal surfaces.
  • Oral involvement commonly presents with burning or discomfort while eating or brushing.
  • Flexural areas like wrists and ankles are the typical sites of distribution.

The majority of patients with cutaneous lesions spontaneously clear within 1 to 2 years after initial presentation, and residual hyperpigmentation of the skin frequently results.

Key Takeaway:
The 5 Ps—pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules—describe classic features; pedunculated lesions are not seen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with intensely pruritic, violaceous, polygonal papules over his wrists and lower back. He has no prior history of skin disease but mentions he had been diagnosed with a viral liver infection years ago. Which of the following infections is associated with lichen planus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hepatitis C virus has the strongest documented association with lichen planus, particularly in regions with high endemicity.

  • Meta-analyses report a 5.4 times higher prevalence of HCV in patients with lichen planus.
  • Routine hepatitis C screening is recommended at the time of first diagnosis of LP.
  • Though causation is not firmly established, immune activation from HCV may trigger type I cytotoxic responses underlying LP.

Triggers of Lichen Planus: 

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus (Option A): Associated with guttate psoriasis, not LP.

HHV-7 (Option C): Linked to pityriasis rosea and DRESS syndrome.

Staphylococcus (Option D): Common in impetigo and abscesses, not lichen planus.

Key Takeaway:
Lichen planus has the strongest viral association with hepatitis C infection; screening is recommended at first diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the images, characterised by white, lacy, reticulated patches on the buccal mucosa, often causing a burning sensation with spicy foods.
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The described features are characteristic of oral lichen planus, particularly the reticular form presenting as lacy white streaks (Wickham’s striae).

  • Oral lichen planus occurs in about 15% of all lichen planus cases, often without cutaneous involvement.
  • Lesions can appear on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and gingiva.
  • A burning sensation with spicy food is typical, especially in erosive forms.
  • Chronic inflammation predisposes to epithelial dysplasia and squamous cell carcinoma, especially in erosive and atrophic variants.
  • Distinct clinical types of mucosal LP include:
    • Reticular type: Most common, asymptomatic white lacy lesions.
    • Erosive type: Painful ulcers, red patches; burning pain.
    • Atrophic type: Erythematous mucosa with discomfort.
    • Hypertrophic type: Rare, thickened mucosal plaques.

Types of Mucosal Lichen Planus

Explanation of other options:
Psoriasis (Option A): Does not involve mucosa; lesions are typically scaly plaques on extensor surfaces.
Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option C): Intensely pruritic vesicles on elbows, knees, and buttocks; mucosal involvement is absent.
Ichthyosis vulgaris (Option D): Dry, scaly skin disorder without mucosal involvement.

Key Takeaway:
Oral lichen planus presents with reticulated white lesions and is the only papulosquamous disorder in this list with mucosal involvement.

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions on the body as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the characteristic nail change of this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pterygium unguis, caused by irreversible scarring of the nail matrix, is the most characteristic nail finding in lichen planus.

  • Nail lichen planus affects up to 10% of LP patients and can occur without adjacent skin lesions.
  • It typically begins with longitudinal ridging and nail plate thinning.
  • Progressive matrix damage leads to pterygium unguis, where the proximal nail fold fuses with the nail bed in a wing-like extension due to a lack of nail plate formation.
  • Severe disease can result in anonychia (complete nail loss).
  • Pup tent sign: A vertical split in the nail plate due to underlying papules, giving a tent-like appearance.
  • Other rare changes include subungual hyperkeratosis, onycholysis, and longitudinal melanonychia.

Nail Changes in Lichen Planus:

Explanation of other options:
Pitting (Option A): Seen in psoriasis and alopecia areata, not characteristic of lichen planus.
Nail plate thinning (Option C): An early feature of LP, but not pathognomonic.
Oil drop sign (Option D): Seen in psoriasis; appears as a translucent yellow-red area under the nail plate.

Key Takeaway:
Pterygium unguis is the hallmark nail change of lichen planus, resulting from irreversible matrix scarring and is rarely seen in other dermatoses.

questions.text: A patient presented with scarring alopecia. On mucosal examination, lacy white reticulate striae are seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lichen planopilaris is a cicatricial alopecia associated with perifollicular inflammation and mucosal Wickham’s striae, making it the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

  • Lichen planopilaris (LPP) is a follicular variant of lichen planus that leads to scarring alopecia.
  • It presents with patchy scalp hair loss due to permanent follicular destruction.
  • Trichoscopy shows perifollicular erythema, perifollicular scaling, and loss of follicular ostia.
  • LPP is often accompanied by Wickham's striae on mucosal surfaces such as the buccal mucosa.
  • Nail or cutaneous LP may coexist.
  • It is considered a T-cell-mediated inflammatory process targeting hair follicles.

Clinical features of Lichen Planopilaris:

Explanation of other options:
Discoid lupus erythematosus (Option A): Features include central follicular plugging and atrophic hypopigmented scars, but lacks mucosal Wickham’s striae.
Dissecting cellulitis (Option C): Presents with nodules, abscesses, and draining sinuses; no mucosal involvement.
Trichotillomania (Option D): Psychiatric hair-pulling disorder; shows broken hairs of varying lengths and lacks mucosal or follicular inflammation.

Key Takeaway:
Lichen planopilaris should be suspected in any case of patchy scarring alopecia with mucosal Wickham’s striae and perifollicular inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterised by basal cell degeneration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basal cell degeneration is a hallmark histopathological feature of lichen planus, caused by CD8+ T-cell–mediated destruction of basal keratinocytes.

  • Degenerating basal cells appear as colloid bodies (also called Civatte or cytoid bodies), either singly or in clusters.
  • These are apoptotic keratinocytes within the basal layer or papillary dermis.
  • The basal layer damage leads to Max-Joseph spaces, small clefts between the epidermis and the dermis.
  • Pigment incontinence occurs due to melanin drop-off into the dermis and phagocytosis by melanophages.
  • The epidermis typically shows hypergranulosis, hyperkeratosis, and irregular saw-toothed rete ridges.
  • Wickham’s striae correspond to an increase in the granular cell layer (hypergranulosis) of the epidermis.
  • A dense band-like lymphocytic infiltrate is seen hugging the dermoepidermal junction.
  • histopathological features of lichen planus:
    • Hyperkeratosis – thickened stratum corneum
    • Acanthosis – thickened stratum malpighii
    • Basal cell degeneration – formation of Max Joseph’s spaces
    • Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction
    • Civatte (colloid) bodies – apoptotic keratinocytes
    • Pigment incontinence – melanin in dermis phagocytosed by macrophages

Explanation of other options:
Pemphigoid (Option A): Subepidermal blistering disorder with separation at the basement membrane—no basal cell degeneration.

Pemphigus (Option C): Intraepidermal acantholysis with flaccid bullae formation—not associated with basal cell injury.

Psoriasis (Option D): Shows regular acanthosis, parakeratosis, and Munro microabscesses, but basal cells are not degenerated.

Key Takeaway:
Basal cell degeneration with Civatte bodies and band-like lymphocytic infiltrate is diagnostic of lichen planus on histopathology.

choices.text: A squamous cell carcinoma is likely to develop.
You should stop taking all medications.
These lesions will probably resolve over time.

questions.text: A dentist notices that his 39-year-old lady patient has some lesions on the buccal mucosa. She also has some skin lesions on her forearms, and a biopsy of a skin lesion showed a band-like infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction, along with degeneration of basal keratinocytes. What would you advise the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with classic clinical and histopathological features of lichen planus (LP):

  • Oral lesions: White, lacy, reticulated patches on the buccal mucosa (Wickham’s striae).
  • Skin lesions: Pruritic, violaceous, polygonal papules, commonly on flexural aspects.
  • Histopathology: Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction (interface dermatitis) with basal cell degeneration (Civatte bodies), Max Joseph spaces.

LP is a chronic, self-limiting inflammatory disease:

  • Cutaneous LP usually resolves within 1–2 years.
  • Oral LP may be more persistent but often improves gradually.
  • LP has a very low (<1%) risk of malignant transformation (to SCC) in chronic erosive oral lesions.

Investigations:

  • Biopsy: Confirms interface dermatitis with basal cell degeneration (shown histologically).
  • Rule out triggers: Hepatitis C serology, medication history (for lichenoid drug reactions), patch testing (for contact allergens).

Management:

  • Topical corticosteroids for local control.
  • Calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus) for mucosal lesions.
  • Systemic corticosteroids or retinoids in extensive/refractory cases.
  • Regular follow-up for erosive oral LP to monitor for malignant change.

Explanation of other options:

A squamous cell carcinoma is likely to develop (Option A): LP carries a very low risk of malignancy; most cases are benign and self-resolving.

You have systemic lupus erythematosus (Option B: SLE shows interface dermatitis but with basal vacuolar change, follicular plugging, and IgG/IgM deposition on immunofluorescence—not seen here.

You should stop taking all medications (Option C): Lichenoid drug eruptions require a clear drug history, which is not provided in this case.

Key Takeaway:
Lichen planus is a self-limited, immune-mediated disorder with characteristic mucocutaneous and histologic features. Oral involvement warrants periodic monitoring.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with multiple, tiny, shiny, pinhead-sized flesh-colored papules over his elbows, knees, and penis. They are discrete, flat-topped, and asymptomatic. No mucosal involvement is seen. Histopathology reveals features similar to early lichen planus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lichen nitidus presents as multiple, minute, discrete, flat-topped, shiny, flesh-colored papules predominantly in children and young adults.

  • Lesions are typically 1–2 mm in diameter, monomorphic, and asymptomatic.
  • Common sites include forearms, elbows, knees, penis, abdomen, and chest.
  • Koebner's phenomenon may be seen.
  • Mucosal involvement is rare, unlike in lichen planus.
  • Nail changes (like pitting or ridging) can occasionally occur.
  • Lesions are self-limiting and typically do not require treatment.

Histopathology (‘claw clutching a ball’ appearance):

  • Well-circumscribed dense lymphohistiocytic infiltrate in the papillary dermis.
  • Surrounded by elongated rete ridges, resembling claws clutching a ball of inflammatory cells.
  • May contain Langhans giant cells and occasional plasma cells.
  • No caseation necrosis or true tubercle formation.
  • On palms, it may show deep parakeratotic plugs, differentiating it from palmar LP.
  • Koebner phenomenon: May be seen in lichen nitidus, similar to LP.
  • Lesions are self-resolving, and no specific treatment is typically required.

Explanation of other options:

Lichen striatus (Option A): Linear distribution of flat-topped papules along Blaschko’s lines; unilateral and often follows viral infection or trauma.

Lichen scrofulosorum (Option B): A miliary tuberculid seen in children with TB; lesions are perifollicular, grouped papules on the trunk.

Lichen planus (Option C): Violaceous, polygonal, pruritic papules with Wickham’s striae; often involves mucosa and nails; histology shows basal cell degeneration and saw-tooth rete ridges.

Key Takeaway:
Lichen nitidus is a benign, self-limited dermatosis in children characterised by tiny, shiny, flat-topped papules and a characteristic "claw clutching a ball" histological appearance.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with asymptomatic lesions on the trunk as shown in the picture. The histopathological report shows perifollicular noncaseating granulomas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lichen scrofulosorum is a form of tuberculid and represents a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens.

  • Occurs primarily in children and adolescents with latent or active TB.
  • Skin lesions: Tiny, grouped, perifollicular, skin-colored to reddish-brown papules, most often located on the trunk, chest, and back.
  • Lesions are usually asymptomatic and may appear suddenly in clusters.

Histopathology:

  • Shows well-formed, non-caseating epithelioid cell granulomas around hair follicles and sweat glands (perifollicular).
  • No caseation necrosis, unlike in true tuberculous lesions.
  • AFB staining is typically negative.
  • A strongly positive Mantoux (tuberculin) test is often observed.

Explanation of other options:

Lichen planus (Option A): Pruritic, violaceous, polygonal papules with Wickham’s striae; histology shows basal cell degeneration and a band-like infiltrate at the dermo-epidermal junction.

Lichen nitidus (Option B): Discrete, flat-topped, shiny papules with “ball-in-claw” appearance on histology; granulomas are not perifollicular.

Lichen sclerosus (Option D): Presents as white, atrophic plaques, usually in the anogenital area; no granulomas seen.

Key Takeaway:
Lichen scrofulosorum is a tuberculid seen in children with underlying TB, presenting with perifollicular papules and non-caseating granulomas.

questions.text: A patient presents with an asymptomatic rash as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image and clinical context are consistent with pityriasis rosea, a self-limiting papulosquamous disorder.

Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting papulosquamous disorder characterized by a herald patch followed by multiple smaller lesions along Langer’s lines (Christmas tree pattern).

  • Aetiology: Associated with reactivation of HHV-6 or HHV-7.
  • Pathophysiology: Delayed-type hypersensitivity to viral antigens results in papulosquamous eruptions.

Clinical Features:

  • Herald patch: Single, round or oval salmon-colored plaque with trailing collarette scale—called the hanging curtain sign.
  • Secondary eruption: Smaller, scaly oval lesions appear along cleavage lines (Langer’s lines) on trunk and proximal limbs, forming a Christmas tree pattern.
  • Lesions: Usually asymptomatic or mildly pruritic.
  • Course: Self-limiting; resolves in 6–8 weeks.

Histopathology:

  • Nonspecific.
  • Shows mild spongiosis, parakeratosis, and superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate.

Explanation of other options:

Tinea corporis (Option A): Fungal infection with annular lesions showing central clearing and active scaly margins; KOH positive—unlike PR.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option C): Greasy yellowish scales over erythematous base, especially on scalp, nasolabial folds, and chest, not in Christmas tree pattern.

Pityriasis alba (Option D): Hypopigmented, fine scaly patches mostly onthe  face of children—no herald patch or widespread distribution.

Key Takeaway:
Pityriasis rosea presents with a herald patch, followed by multiple oval lesions along Langer’s lines in a Christmas tree pattern, with characteristic collarette scaling (hanging curtain sign).

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a large oval plaque over her trunk, followed days later by multiple scaly eruptions along Langer's lines. Which of the following viral agents is most strongly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Pityriasis rosea is associated with reactivation of HHV-6 and HHV-7, most strongly supported by detection of viral DNA in blood and lesional skin.

  • Human Herpesvirus 6 and 7 (especially HHV-7) are believed to be reactivated from latency, triggering the eruption.
  • Viral DNA of HHV-7 is detected more frequently than HHV-6 in lesional and non-lesional skin, suggesting a pathogenic link.
  • Herpesvirus-like particles are found in up to 71% of pityriasis rosea lesions.
  • It typically affects children and young adults and shows seasonal clustering, further supporting a viral aetiology.

Additional Associations:

  • Pityriasis rosea–like eruptions have been reported following vaccinations (BCG, influenza, hepatitis B, pneumococcus, SARS-CoV-2) and drugs (gold salts, clonidine, D-penicillamine, captopril).
  • Herald patch followed by multiple scaly plaques in a Christmas tree distribution is the hallmark.

Explanation of other options:

CMV (Option B): Commonly causes mononucleosis-like illness or congenital infection, but no established link with pityriasis rosea.

Varicella Zoster (Option C): Causes chickenpox and shingles; not associated with pityriasis rosea.

EBV (Option D): Associated with infectious mononucleosis and lymphoproliferative disorders, not with pityriasis rosea.

Key Takeaway:
Pityriasis rosea is most strongly associated with HHV-6 and HHV-7, especially the latter, supported by histological and molecular evidence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with multiple erythematous annular lesions with peripheral scales arranged predominantly on the trunk. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The condition described is pityriasis rosea (PR), a self-limiting papulosquamous disorder typically seen in adolescents and young adults.

Approach:

  • As pityriasis rosea is self-limiting, treatment is supportive and directed at symptom relief.
  • Most cases resolve spontaneously within 6–8 weeks.
  • Mild to moderate potency topical steroids are first-line for symptomatic relief, especially for itching or inflammation.
  • Antihistamines and emollients may also be used for supportive care.
  • In cases of severe disease or pregnancy-associated pityriasis rosea, acyclovir may be considered early during the course.

Explanation of other options:

Systemic steroids (Option B): Not required for PR, as the condition resolves on its own, and systemic steroids are reserved for severe, symptomatic cases only.

Systemic azathioprine (Option C): An immunosuppressive agent, not indicated in PR.

Topical antifungal (Option D): Ineffective as PR is not of fungal aetiology; used for tinea corpori,s which must be ruled out clinically or via KOH mount.

questions.text: Identify the disorder in which the following clinical picture is seen:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) is a rare chronic papulosquamous disorder characterised by follicular papules and sharply demarcated islands of sparing.

Definition:
PRP is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disorder affecting both children and adults. Shows a cephalocaudal spread with characteristic clinical features.

Clinical Features:

  • Initial presentation: Diffuse fine scaling on the scalp.
  • Progression: Papules coalesce into plaques that spread in a cephalocaudal manner.
  • Classic hallmark: Orange-red follicular hyperkeratotic papules with intervening normal skin — described as "islands of sparing".
  • May evolve into generalised erythroderma.
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma: Red-orange thickening of palms and soles – described as "sandal-like PPK".
  • Nail changes: Thickening, discolouration, and subungual hyperkeratosis may occur.
  • Juvenile classic PRP often resolves spontaneously.

Pathology & Investigations (Histology):

  • Epidermis: Alternating horizontal and vertical orthokeratosis and parakeratosis (checkerboard pattern).
  • Hair follicles: Follicular plugging and irregular acanthosis.
  • Dermis: Sparse superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate.
  • These histopathological findings help distinguish PRP from psoriasis and eczema.

Explanation of other options:

Psoriasis (Option A): Characterised by silvery-white scales and symmetrical plaques; lacks follicular accentuation and islands of sparing.

Eczema (Option B): Typically vesicular in acute stages, with crusting and oozing, not follicular-based or progressing to erythroderma.

Lichen nitidus (Option C): Tiny, flat-topped, shiny papules; not associated with cephalocaudal spread, palmoplantar keratoderma, or islands of sparing.

Key Takeaway:
Pityriasis rubra pilaris is a chronic dermatosis presenting with orange-red follicular papules, islands of sparing, cephalocaudal progression, and waxy palmoplantar keratoderma.

choices.text: Isolated patches of normal skin are found

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Cyclosporine is generally ineffective in the management of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP). While it is used in various inflammatory skin disorders like psoriasis, PRP does not respond well to cyclosporine and is managed with other modalities.

PRP is a rare, chronic, inflammatory papulosquamous disorder characterised by follicular papules, palmoplantar keratoderma, and islands of sparing. It shows cephalocaudal progression and affects both adults and children.

Clinical Features:

  • Orange-red follicular hyperkeratotic papules
  • Cephalocaudal spread of lesions(Option B)
  • Sharply demarcated "islands of sparing"(Option A)
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma (sandal-like)
  • May progress to erythroderma in severe cases
  • No gender or ethnic predilection(Option D)

Management:

Topical Therapy (for mild/localised disease):

  • Emollients
  • Keratolytics (urea, salicylic acid, lactic acid)
  • Topical corticosteroids
  • Calcineurin inhibitors

Systemic Therapy:

  • First-line:
    • Oral retinoids (Isotretinoin, Acitretin, Alitretinoin)
    • Retinoids act via antiproliferative, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory effects.
    • Isotretinoin shows marked improvement in most patients within 4 weeks.
  • Second-line:
    • Methotrexate (especially in recalcitrant cases or in combination with retinoids)
    • Useful but requires liver monitoring for toxicity.
  • Biologics:
    • Anti-TNF agents (e.g., Infliximab, Etanercept)
    • Ustekinumab (IL-12/23 blocker) has shown rapid and dramatic improvement even in refractory or familial PRP.
    • Anti-IL-17 agents – variable but promising responses.

Not Effective:

  • Cyclosporine – inconsistent or poor efficacy; not recommended for PRP treatment.

Key Takeaway:
Cyclosporine is not effective in PRP. Retinoids, methotrexate, and biologics form the mainstay of systemic treatment depending on disease severity.

questions.text: Kerato dermic sandals is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) is the only condition among the options that shows the "sandal-like" palmoplantar keratoderma, often referred to as keratodermic sandals due to its distribution and orange-red waxy appearance.

Palmoplantar keratoderma – classically waxy, red-orange thickening, likened to “keratodermic sandals” due to their well-demarcated distribution and colour

Clinical Features of PRP:

  • Follicular hyperkeratotic papules (nutmeg grater texture)
  • Cephalocaudal progression of lesions
  • Orange-red erythroderma
  • Islands of sparing
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma
  • Nail involvement may occur with subungual hyperkeratosis and dystrophy
  • Mucosal lesions are rare

Explanation of Other Options:

Pityriasis rosea (Option A): Characterised by a herald patch and Christmas tree-like distribution on the trunk; no palmoplantar keratoderma.

Lichen planus (Option B): Presents with violaceous, pruritic, polygonal papules; palmoplantar thickening is not seen in classical LP.

Psoriasis (Option C): Features include silvery-scaled plaques, nail pitting, and Auspitz sign; palmoplantar psoriasis exists but lacks the sandal pattern or orange-red waxy appearance typical of PRP.

Key Takeaway:

"Keratodermic sandals" refers to the classic red-orange waxy palmoplantar keratoderma seen in PRP, a distinguishing feature from other papulosquamous disorders.

questions.text: All are causes of papulosquamous lesions except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a vesiculobullous disorder, not a papulosquamous one. It is characterised by grouped vesicles and papules, usually with intense pruritus, and is associated with gluten sensitivity.

Papulosquamous disorders are a group of dermatological conditions that present with scaling papules or plaques, often with inflammation and epidermal hyperproliferation.

Common Causes of Papulosquamous Lesions:

Explanation of Other Options:

Psoriasis (Option A): Classic papulosquamous disease with silvery scales and chronic plaques.

Pityriasis rosea (Option B): Self-limiting condition presenting with scaly papules in a Christmas tree pattern.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option C): Specifically, Bowen’s disease (SCC in situ) can present as papulosquamous lesions and is included in this group.

Key Takeaway:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a vesiculobullous disorder and not included under papulosquamous diseases, making it the correct exception in this list.
